content.title: Subclavian Artery Disease
content.definition: Atherosclerotic stenosis or occlusion of the subclavian artery proximal to the vertebral artery origin, causing upper extremity claudication and potentially subclavian steal phenomenon (reversal of vertebral artery flow with vertebrobasilar symptoms).

key_concepts.description: Left subclavian artery arises directly from aortic arch (more susceptible to atherosclerosis); right from brachiocephalic trunk. Vertebral artery origin is key landmark
Left-sided involvement more common (3:1); atherosclerosis is primary cause (>95%); prevalence 2-5% in general population; often asymptomatic
Arm claudication (fatigue/pain with arm exercise); arm weakness; cold sensitivity; rarely limb-threatening due to excellent collaterals (rarely develops critical ischemia)
Stenosis proximal to vertebral origin causes pressure drop → vertebral artery flow reverses to supply arm → steals blood from basilar artery → vertebrobasilar insufficiency symptoms
Arm exercise triggers vertebrobasilar symptoms: dizziness, syncope, visual changes, ataxia, diplopia. Must have both anatomic steal AND symptoms to be syndrome
Blood pressure differential >15-20 mmHg between arms; diminished ipsilateral radial pulse; subclavicular bruit; may have signs of digital ischemia (rare)
In patients with LIMA-LAD bypass graft, proximal subclavian stenosis can cause reversal of graft flow → myocardial ischemia with arm exercise. Screen before CABG
Duplex ultrasound showing reversal of vertebral flow; CTA/MRA for anatomy; BP differential >15 mmHg prompts workup
Symptomatic steal syndrome; upper extremity claudication affecting function; before CABG with LIMA; hemodialysis access planned
Endovascular: subclavian artery stenting (primary therapy now); Surgical: carotid-subclavian bypass, subclavian-carotid transposition

content.statement: Subclavian Artery Disease is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Subclavian-Artery that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Subclavian Artery Disease helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Subclavian Artery Disease include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Subclavian Artery Disease.

learning_objectives: Define subclavian steal physiology and syndrome
Recognize the clinical presentation (BP differential, symptoms)
Understand the relevance to coronary artery bypass (LIMA steal)
clinical_pearls: >15-20 mmHg arm BP differential = suspect subclavian disease
Steal physiology (flow reversal) is common; steal SYNDROME (symptoms) is less common
Screen for subclavian stenosis before LIMA-LAD bypass
Endovascular stenting is now primary treatment
common_mistakes: Diagnosing steal syndrome when only steal physiology present
Not checking arm BPs bilaterally (always measure both)
Not screening before CABG with planned LIMA
